Most Illustrious Sir

The two letters from Your Lordship dated the 28th and 30th of last month were presented to the government, and the matter therein was well understood, approving the measures taken by Your Lordship.

And regarding the last part of your letter, in which you speak of the woman pointed out as dangerous to the tranquility of this department, since she somehow favored the enemy’s entry: the government orders that, after Your Lordship

The attached letter, I beg Your Lordship

May God keep Your Lordship Secretary of War Affairs in Caçapava, May 14, 1840 Most Illustrious Sir Inácio José de Oliveira Guimarães. Serafim Joaquim de Alencastre

Letter from the Most Excellent, May 14, received on the 28th of the same month, concerning the information I gave about the enemy, and the woman accused as an enemy, etc., etc.
